div.head: Section 5
div.p: Since in the beginning of the responsive conclusion to the raised question we excluded also our illustrious and most Christian king, namely that not even his highness without the license and free consent of King Inca, and indeed a great king of the kingdoms of Peru, or of other kings or petty kings to whom it pertains, or their heirs, can send or order to inquire or search and take treasures and other precious things which are in tombs etc., therefore we judge it worthy to render an account of such matters.

And it is proved thus: That King Inca and his successors are princes and supreme and universal lords of all the kingdoms of Peru, not recognizing a superior, and they have just pure and mixed imperium a nd all manner of power and jurisdiction, just as other free kings of the world.
Therefore no king or prince in the world can without his or their license and good pleasure enter those kingdoms and seek or search for what is in them and take them.

The antecedent is clear: because that whole world, of which those kingdoms of Peru are part, is most remote in the highest ocean sea from every other region of all those which men have ever known, which we found occupied and possessed by those Indians living there and proper kings reigning over them,
and thus exempt from every superior or free. And these things are sufficiently proved by
l. ex hoc iure
with the note there by the doctors: by this law the peoples were distinguished, kingdoms founded by individual peoples who elected kings for themselves according to
the gloss "dominia distincta"
and
gratia ff de iustitia et iure , where it appears that by natural and law of nations those peoples and their kings are lords and free, recognizing no one as superior, neither by right nor in fact, before we recognized them.

Moreover that one is called a superior to whom the place pertains from the nature of the place, that is by outcome:
Baldus said allegatio l. insule ff. de iudiciis . But better in
consilio 328 primae par. ultima questio , where he says:
it makes no difference whether someone is called king or duke, because force is not to be applied to the name but to the quality of rule and the magnitude of power, argumentum ff. de conditionibus et demonstrationibus l. pater severinam § conditionum ; thus Baldus, and far better still
the same 2e par. for our proposition
says thus:
that by the law of nations kings hold the supreme position even among infidels and therefore appeal is not made from them; it also appears that with kings there is that species of lordship which is called universal, but the particular pertains to individuals per se, but to the king per accidens, that is through an accidental cause, for example on account of a crime, and therefore
etc. According to Saint Thomas however and...

But according to Saint Thomas however in
book 1, chapter 14, on the rule of princes , we suppose that king to be called to whom
the highest rule in human affairs is committed . Indeed he who is elected as superior by the people or who succeeded one thus elected when he was elected with his successors...
l. ex hoc iure with the note there. Moreover jurisdiction is planted in a place or territory from which it cannot be pulled out; it applies
l. in modicis ff. de contrahenda emptio
and
l. 1, § cum urbem ff. de officio prefecti urbis
and
l. fina eo titulo
and
l. 3. de officio presidis
and
l. 2 ff. de iurisdictione omnium iudicum , in which it is said that
jurisdiction coheres to territory . To this
c. fi. de constitutionibus libro 6
and in
l. fi.
where and among whom, and in
l. pupillus § territorium ff. de verborum significatione
and
l. quicumque Codex de fundis limitrophis lib. 11 .
Whence because the king has his kingdom and the whole soil of that kingdom consists in his power (d. § cum urbem), therefore he also has jurisdiction cohering to that whole soil or territory.

Indeed the consequence is proved because by entering another's kingdom without license and especially with an army against the will or tacit or express prohibition of the proper king, he is said to disturb him by simple entry, whence he commits injury to him, and by taking anything from there, especially something precious, he usurps what is another's,
argumentum ff de iniuriis l. iniuriarum § si quis me prohibeat
and
§ fi.
and
l. sane , and
l. is qui in domum alienam
and
1 dist. c. 1. Cyrus
in
l. 1, Codex uti possidetis .
Bartholus in l. 1 § interdictum 3 columna eo Baldus in l. sentiam vel columna in principio verb. porro si ego possideo .

Whence any king or universal moderator of any kingdom not recognizing a superior, if he sees it expedient for peace and quiet, for avoiding bad morals, for the defense, security and conservation of the kingdom or his republic in liberty, can establish or by royal law prohibit that no one of foreigners or aliens or any person of another kingdom may enter the kingdom or province or city of his jurisdiction, either for the sake of trade, exchange, buying and selling, or for the sake of dwelling or inhabiting, or for any other reason. And he will do this reasonably and prudently, since it pertains to royal circumspection and care to provide for future dangers of the kingdom or republic, so that it may be rendered safe against external enemies. Since not only is what is present attended to, but also what can be, because outcomes are in the consideration of men,
l. pater filio ff. de heredibus instituendis ,
l. ait facto § euentus ff. de penis
and
§ posteriore inst. quibus modis testa. infra.
and
l. generaliter § si libero homini ff. de fide commisariis libertatibus . That moreover a king could prohibit the entry of foreigners will be clear
below § 12 .

Indeed by these things which we have just touched upon and explained with brief delay, and in our work on the only way of calling all peoples to the true religion
book 1, chapter 3 , which were elucidated with the widest discourse, we think that no one exists who would not freely assent unless he suffers either some defect of mind or inexperience of Catholic doctrine.

To these things, however, only the papal institution seems to stand in the way, made concerning our kings of Spain as superiors over the kings and moderators of that whole Indian world, by virtue and authority of which, since all peoples and inhabitants of those lands remain subjects of our kings by reason of the faith to be preached, therefore all other things which follow persons seem to be subject to them, and consequently they can decree or determine about all things which are in the kingdoms, and thus about the aforesaid treasures and whatever is precious, at pleasure or by arbitration as supreme princes.

Whence although all things determined in the preceding are true as regards any other kings of the world, nevertheless not as regards the kings of Spain, who by peculiar privilege and donation through the apostolic see were elevated to imperial height over that world.

To which we say that it is indeed true that the Catholic kings of Castile and Leon were constituted by the providence and gracious donation of the apostolic see as supreme princes over that world by reason of the care which the same holy see enjoined upon them for preaching the faith and converting the inhabitants of it, as appears in the apostolic letters of the aforesaid institution or donation.

But truly not by the law itself or by the very fact that such our kings were named or instituted by the supreme pontiff was the dominion of that entire world transferred to them, nor possession, according to what is noted by the legists in
l. traditionibus C. de pactis
and in
aut. ingressi. C. de sacrosanctis ecclesiis
and in
l. nunquam ff. de acquirendo rerum dominio
and by the canonists in
c. ex literis de consuetudine
and in other places of both laws.
